results.title: The Trouble with medicine. [Part 2]
results.creator_credit: Martin Freeth, Stefan Moore, BBC and WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.)
results.brief_description: Last three episodes of a major and controversial international series which looks at the challenges that face medical science today. “Disordered states” (Dir: Peter Montagnon): Explores mental illness and how the treatment of patients differs in different countries. India, Italy and the United States are shown as examples. “Pandemic” (Dir: Susan Lambert, Stefan Moore): Looks at AIDS programs in the USA where the high-tech approach to medicine is out of reach of most of those who need it, in Thailand, where the entire population is at threat, and in Australia where there has been some success in containing the disease. “Life support” (Dir: Henry Singer) The final episode looks at how modern medicine deals with the frail, elderly and the dying, exploring issues such as when is enough life support enough? Warning - some scenes in this video may disturb some viewers.

results.title: The Trouble with medicine. [Part 1]
results.creator_credit: Martin Freeth, Stefan Moore, BBC and WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.)
results.brief_description: The first three episodes of a major and controversial international series which looks at the challenges that face medical science today. “Conceiving the future” (Dir: Tim Clark): Looks at genetics and the ethical dilemmas that arise from new technologies and being further able to pinpoint defects and abnormalities in unborn children. Asking questions such as what is abnormal? “Code of silence” (Dir: Stephen White): Examines to the heart of the doctor/patient relationship to find some extreme differences in the way physicians talk to their clients. “Temple of science” (Dir: Stefan Moore): Looks at the trend towards hi-tech medicine and specialisation, and Australia’s lead being the U.S.A. Warning: some scenes may be disturbing to some viewers.

results.title: They called me stupid (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Tom Kelly and Canadian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description: Focuses on the problems of dyslexia, a condition which causes great distress to children and adults, since it results in difficulties in reading and consequently also in learning. One theory is that it is a listening rather than a seeing complaint. Examines a new invention, called the “Electronic ear” which has proved helpful in many cases.

results.title: They called it 'fire proof'
results.creator_credit: Roger Blais and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: It was considered a fireproof hospital, yet fire did break out. The building was modern in construction; reasonable safety precautions were observed; but all this proved insufficient. The film argues the case for safety-consciousness and constant vigilance by the entire staff of any institutional building.

results.title: They appreciate you more
results.creator_credit: Kathleen Shannon and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Aliette lives in Montreal with her husband and three children. Since both Aliette and Pierre work outside their home full-time, they share household responsibilities. This development has changed them as individuals and, they think, has affected the dynamics of their family - for the better. This film is interesting for mixed audiences of women and men.

results.title: They all can work
results.creator_credit: Brian Pollard, Rex Tasker and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Natural Recovery Systems of Moncton, New Brunswick, is a recycling factory. The employees are efficient and conscientious. All are eligible for on-the-job training and an after-hours life-skills program. They are mentally and physically disabled, a resource of forgotten people. The film shows them on and off the job, learning new skills, and generally relaxing among themselves in the company cafeteria. Narrated by Joseph Rutten. (Award: New York.)

results.title: There we are John...Derek Jarman interviewed by John Cartwright
results.creator_credit: Ken McMullen, Guy Landver, Hannah Wiggin and British Council
results.brief_description: Controversial director Derek Jarman talks one on one with John Cartwright at Dungeness about his work. Throughout the beautifully shot interview, Jarman discusses various issues including being labelled a director as opposed to a painter, film technique in the 1980s (especially working with Super 8), the incorrect assumption that his work is avant-garde, public reaction to his films “Sebastiane” (1976) and “Jubilee” (1978), “The Tempest” (1979), “Caravaggio” (1986), “The Garden” (1990), “Last of England” (1987), the film he forgot he made - “War requiem” (1989), and the film he remembers most fondly - “The Angelic conversation” (1985). Jarman also talks about converting “Edward II” (1991) to screen and his selection of images (or lack thereof) in his personal tribute to his experience of battling with AIDS; “Blue” (1993).
